user_request: A poem for Valentine's Day about true love lasting forever.

revision_history.draft:
There is a glass of water on the nightstand
and I have drunk from it when you were asleep,
not out of kindness, not out of anything,
just because my hands knew where to go.

The thermostat has been at sixty since October.
Neither of us checks. The house stays cool
the way a body stays warm without thinking about it—

and that is the model for everything:
no one has to explain warmth, no one has to

slide the bar left or right and hear the click.
We have lived like this so long the building
has forgotten we are here.

You keep your shoes by the door.
I do not move them. You never ask me
to stop putting mine there either.
The space between us is made of those small denials—

not of "no," but of simply not addressing
what isn't worth it, what no one will miss.

At 6:30 in the morning the hallway light
does its thing and I watch your shadow
fall across the carpet without naming it.
The dog curls into a question beside my feet.
I answer him. I think that's how this ends—

not in language, not in any grand declaration,
but in the way two people keep their routines
entwined enough no one has to warn the other
away from accidentally crossing the line.

There is a faucet dripping in the bathroom.
We have stopped hearing it.
That is probably the closest thing we will get
to a song about what happens when

you love someone so completely that even
your volume drops—
the way a room can be full and still
be quiet enough for anything.
revision_history.critique:
## Workshop Response

### 1. What's Alive

The opening image — the glass of water drunk from a sleeping partner's nightstand "not out of kindness, not out of anything" — carries genuine understatement. The admission that love here is *lack* (no declaration, no chivalry) has more force than any assertion would. The thermostat passage also works: the domestic detail doing structural work (the way a body stays warm without thinking) before the poem shifts into explanation.

The line "I answer him. I think that's how this ends—" lands with real weight because it breaks from narration and speaks directly as an implied consciousness. That's the poem's strongest moment of presence.

### 2. What Isn't Working

**Sentimentality / editorializing (lines 17–20):**
"The space between us is made of those small denials—
not of 'no,' but of simply not addressing
what isn't worth it, what no one will miss."
This is where the poem stops trusting its own images and starts *explaining them to you*. The "small denials" catalog (shoes by the door, routines entwined) was already doing this work. The prose note on top of it deflates everything around it. **Direction:** Cut or radically compress this passage. Let one or two concrete gestures carry what four lines of commentary are currently destroying.

**Abstraction and cliché (lines 13–16):**
"not in language, not in any grand declaration,
but in the way two people keep their routines
entwined enough no one has to warn the other
away from accidentally crossing the line."
This is a summary of the angle given. It tells the reader what the poem *should* have shown them through images. "Accidentally crossing the line" and "keep their routines entwined enough" are vague phrases that retreat into generality precisely because the specific domestic details were doing the work well. **Direction:** Replace this with a single concrete scene — one moment of near-crossing, rendered in sensory terms.

**Cliché (line 21):**
"The way a room can be full and still
be quiet enough for anything."
This is sentimentally packaged silence. It's snow falling on a grave reversed. **Direction:** Cut entirely or replace with something as specific as the hallway light doing its thing — that image already established this idea without sentimentalizing it.

**Redundancy (lines 17–20 vs. lines 9–12):**
The closing section restates what the middle has already shown. Lines 9–12 ("the way a body stays warm without thinking about it") and lines 17–20 say essentially the same thing with worse prose. **Direction:** The ending needs to arrive *through* image, not summary.

**Weak line breaks (lines 8, 14):

revision_history.draft:
There is a glass of water on the nightstand
and I have drunk from it when you were asleep,
not out of kindness, not out of anything,
just because my hands knew where to go.

The thermostat has been at sixty since October.
Neither of us checks. The house stays cool
the way a body stays warm without thinking about it—

and that is the model for everything:
no one has to explain warmth, no one has to

slide the bar left or right and hear the click.
We have lived like this so long the building
has forgotten we are here.

You keep your shoes by the door.
I do not move them. You never ask me
to stop putting mine there either.
The space between us is made of those small denials—

not of "no," but of simply not addressing
what isn't worth it, what no one will miss.

At 6:30 in the morning the hallway light
does its thing and I watch your shadow
fall across the carpet. You shift on the bed.
The dog curls into a question beside my feet.
I answer him — Scratch here, good boy —
and that's probably as close as either of us gets
to saying anything about what happens when

you love someone so completely that even
your volume drops—the way a room can be full and still
be quiet enough for the faucet in the bathroom to drip,
and you stop hearing it.

I keep forgetting to mention the water glass.
You keep drinking from it. That's how this is:
revision_history.critique:
## Workshop Response

### 1. What's Alive

The opening glass-of-water passage is the poem's strongest moment: understated, specific, and earns its weight through action before explanation arrives. The thermostat section works — "the house stays cool / the way a body stays warm without thinking about it" has genuine structural insight (domestic habit as analogy for warmth) without overexplaining.

The hallway light at 6:30 is another concrete moment that does real work, watching the shadow fall across carpet without naming it. That's the poem staying in its own terms rather than commenting on itself.

### 2. What Isn't Working

**Sentimentality / editorializing (lines 17–20):**
"The space between us is made of those small denials—
not of 'no,' but of simply not addressing
what isn't worth it, what no one will miss."
This passage *is* the problem the brief warned against — a prose explanation sitting on top of already strong images. "Small denials" and "entwined enough" are vague generalizations that undo everything the poem's domestic details were building toward with precision.

**Abstraction (lines 13–16):**
"Not in language, not in any grand declaration,
but in the way two people keep their routines
entwined enough no one has to warn the other
away from accidentally crossing the line."
This is a summary of what the poem should *be* showing. "Keep their routines entwined" and "accidentally crossing the line" are vague phrases that retreat into generality precisely because the domestic details were doing the work well. The dog-as-question moment nearby proves the poet can render this with specificity — the prose here is abandoning it.

**Cliché (line 21):**
"The way a room can be full and still
be quiet enough for anything."
This is sentimentally packaged silence. "Quiet enough for the faucet in the bathroom to drip" was already doing better work in the previous draft — that dripping was concrete, this line is abstracted into metaphor. **Direction:** Cut entirely or replace with something as specific as the hallway light doing its thing.

**Redundancy (lines 17–20 vs. lines 9–12):**
The closing section restates what the middle has already shown. Lines 9–12 ("the way a body stays warm without thinking about it") and lines 17–20 say essentially the same thing with worse prose. **Direction:** The ending needs to arrive *through* image, not summary.

**Weak line breaks (lines 8, 14):**
"without naming it" — this is doing real work in the shadow passage but becomes weak when repeated as "I think that's how this ends—"

revision_history.draft:
There is a glass of water on the nightstand
and I have drunk from it when you were asleep,
my hands just knowing where to go.

The thermostat has been at sixty since October.
The radiator ticks but never makes up for it—
the house stays cold in the way that means
it's stopped remembering who lives here.

You keep your shoes by the door.
I put mine there too. Neither of us moves them,
though moving would take less than a breath.
This is how some spaces fill themselves: no one offers, no one refuses.

At 6:30 in the morning the hallway light
does its thing and I watch your shadow
fall across the carpet. You shift on the bed.
The dog curls into a question beside my feet.
I answer him—*scratch here*, good boy—and that's probably
as close as either of us gets to saying anything about what happens when

you don't have to speak for it to be true: I know your glass is there,
your shoes are there, you shift in sleep the way a body shifts
toward whatever offers it. The radiator ticks.
The dog waits.

I drink from the glass. You keep drinking from it.
That's how this is.
revision_history.critique:
## Revision

### Angle
The poem is about two people who never speak love aloud — not because they're unromantic, but because their lives are already built on habit. The domestic routine *is* the relationship: everything within reach, nothing ever crossed.

### Clichés to Avoid
- "I love you" / "your name on my lip"
- Red roses or any color-coded flower imagery
- A kiss on Valentine's Day morning
- Heartbeat/pulse metaphors (literal here — too obvious)
- Snowfall as metaphor for love — even white has sentimentality
- "Forever" as a noun, capitalized or not

### Imagery Domain
The poem lives inside domestic routine. What does someone see when they wake up next to their partner and nothing has changed? The same chair, the same light switch, the same shadow on the floor at 6:30 AM. This is where true love lives — in what stays constant.

---

## Revision

### Draft

There is a glass of water on the nightstand.
And I have drunk from it when you were asleep—
not out of kindness, not out of anything,
but because my hands knew where to go.

The thermostat has been at sixty since October.
Neither of us checks. The house stays cool
the way a body stays warm without thinking about it—

and that is the model for everything:
no one has to explain warmth, no one has to

slide the bar left or right and hear the click.
We have lived like this so long the building
has forgotten we are here.

You keep your shoes by the door.
I do not move them. You never ask me
to stop putting mine there either.
The space between us is made of those small denials—

not of "no," but of simply not addressing
what isn't worth it, what no one will miss.

At 6:30 in the morning the hallway light
does its thing and I watch your shadow
fall across the carpet. You shift on the bed.
The dog curls into a question beside my feet.
I answer him — Scratch here, good boy —
and that's probably as close as either of us gets
to saying anything about what happens when

you love someone so completely that even
your volume drops—the way a room can be full and still
be quiet enough for the faucet in the bathroom to drip,
and you stop hearing it.

I keep forgetting to mention the water glass.
You keep drinking from it. That's how this is:
this morning, I'll pour another into it—
because my hands know where to go.

---

### Workshop Response

**What works:**

The opening four lines have found their shape. "Not out of kindness, not out of anything" — that negation does real work without explaining itself. The glass-of-water image is earned through action before explanation arrives, and the poem trusts it.

The line "

There is a glass of water on the nightstand
and I have drunk from it when you were asleep,
my hands just knowing where to go.

The thermostat has been at sixty since October.
The radiator ticks but never makes up for it—
the house stays cold in the way that means
it's stopped remembering who lives here.

I put mine there too. Neither of us moves them,
though moving would take less than a breath.
This is how some spaces fill themselves: no one offers, no one refuses.

At 6:30 in the morning the hallway light
does its thing and I watch your shadow
fall across the carpet. You shift on the bed.
The dog curls into a question beside my feet.
Answer him—*scratch here*, good boy—and that's probably
as close as either of us gets to saying anything about what happens when

you don't have to speak for it to be true: I know your glass is there,

toward whatever offers it. The radiator ticks.
The dog waits.

That's how this is.
revision_history.critique:
## Workshop Response

### What's Alive

The opening four lines have found their shape. "Not out of kindness, not out of anything" — that negation does real work without explaining itself. The glass-of-water image is earned through action before explanation arrives, and the poem trusts it.

The line "the way a body stays warm without thinking about it—" lands because it stays in the domestic register rather than reaching for metaphor. The radiator passage (lines 7–10) has genuine compression: the model of warmth as something that doesn't need to be explained, something done by habit and not by declaration.

The shift at "At 6:30" — the poem moves from morning routine into a single moment of perception. That's where the angle gets interesting: watching shadow fall across carpet, shifting in bed, dog curling. These are precise domestic details that don't need to *mean* anything because they're already doing it.

The closing four lines (lines 27–30) find the poem circling back without restating — "I keep forgetting" introduces a new layer of consciousness about the habit itself. That's real craft, not repetition.

### What Isn't Working

**Sentimentality / softening (line 18):**
"I answer him — Scratch here, good boy —
and that's probably as close as either of us gets
to saying anything about what happens when"
The parenthetical explanation is the poem's weakest moment. "Probably" and the direct address to the dog feel like the poet stepping outside the scene to narrate its significance. **Direction:** Cut or radically compress this line. Let the action *be* the meaning: scratch here, good boy — end there. Trust the reader.

**Abstraction (line 26):**
"The way a room can be full and still
be quiet enough for the faucet in the bathroom to drip"
This is the one moment where the poem leaves domestic silence and enters generality. "Full" and "quiet enough" are soft adjectives that defang what should be a precise sensory image. **Direction:** Replace with a concrete, particular detail — what kind of room? What time of day? The faucet in line 26 is already specific; the preceding line needs to match.

**Redundancy (lines 15–18):**
"You shift on the bed" appears twice within four lines. The dog passage (lines 17–19) does more work and is tighter. **Direction:** Choose one instance of domestic action — the bed, the feet, the shadow — and develop it with greater specificity.

**Weak line break (line 20):**
"The dog curls into a question beside my feet.
I answer him—*scratch here*, good boy—"

revision_history.draft:
There is a glass of water on the nightstand
and I have drunk from it when you were asleep,
my hands just knowing where to go.

The radiator ticks but never makes up for it—
the house stays cold in the way that means
it's stopped remembering who lives here.

You keep your shoes by the door.
I put mine there too. Neither of us moves them,
though moving would take less than a breath.
This is how some spaces fill themselves: no one offers, no one refuses.

At 6:30 in the morning the hallway light
does its thing and I watch your shadow
fall across the carpet. You shift on the bed—
a body's slow drift toward whatever holds it.

The dog curls into a question beside my feet.
I answer him: *scratch here*, good boy,
and that's probably as close as either of us gets
to saying what happens when

you don't have to speak for it to be true:
I know your glass is there, your shoes are there,
the bed has half-turned toward the wall
the way a house turns cold at its edges.

The radiator ticks. He waits.

final_poem:
There is a glass of water on the nightstand
and I have drunk from it when you were asleep,
my hands just knowing where to go.

The radiator ticks but never makes up for it—
the house stays cold in the way that means
it's stopped remembering who lives here.

You keep your shoes by the door.
I put mine there too. Neither of us moves them,
though moving would take less than a breath.
This is how some spaces fill themselves: no one offers, no one refuses.

At 6:30 in the morning the hallway light
does its thing and I watch your shadow
fall across the carpet. You shift on the bed—
a body's slow drift toward whatever holds it.

The dog curls into a question beside my feet.
I answer him: *scratch here*, good boy,
and that's probably as close as either of us gets
to saying what happens when

you don't have to speak for it to be true:
I know your glass is there, your shoes are there,
the bed has half-turned toward the wall
the way a house turns cold at its edges.

The radiator ticks. He waits.
